Question_1.Context: The study focused on fabricating a novel composite membrane for water purification. The membrane was modified with polyelectrolytes to improve rejection performance.
Question_1.Question: What was the primary reason behind the high dye rejection efficiency of the PSS-PDA-crosslinked GO membrane?
Question_1.Source: The solid electrostatic interaction of polyelectrolytes with the bacterial cell membrane may damage the cell wall.

Question_2.Context: The study evaluated the rejection performance of different membranes after exposure to chlorine solutions of varying concentrations.
Question_2.Question: What was the primary reason behind the excellent chlorine tolerance property of the PSS-PDA-crosslinked GO membrane?
Question_2.A: Entrapment of free chlorine into primary or secondary amine of polydopamine
Question_2.Source: The resistance towards chlorine exposure of this membrane can explain that free chlorine may be entrapped into primary or secondary amine of polydopamine.

Question_3.Context: The study investigated the antifouling characteristics of the membranes in dynamic conditions.
Question_3.Question: What was the primary reason behind the high FRR values of the PSS-PDA-crosslinked GO membrane?
Question_3.Source: The surface charge brought by the assembly of the polycations and polyanions is the primary reason behind the high FRR values of the PSS-PDA-crosslinked GO membrane.

Question_4.Context: The study assessed the rejection performance of the membranes in forward osmosis mode.
Question_4.Question: What was the primary reason behind the significant rejection efficiency of the PSS-PDA-crosslinked GO membrane for both monovalent and divalent ions?
Question_4.A: Electrostatic interaction in addition to pore-based sieving
Question_4.Source: The PSS-PDA-crosslinked GO membrane's highest efficiency is because of electrostatic interaction in addition to the pore-based sieving.

Question_5.Context: The study examined the water flux of different membranes at a specific transmembrane pressure.
Question_5.Question: What was the primary reason behind the significant flux improvement observed in the PSS-PDA membrane?
Question_5.Source: The charge surface resists the fouling attack by repelling the negative charged BSA used as a model foulant.

Question_6.Context: The study investigated the antibacterial efficiency of the membranes against E. coli and S. aureus.
Question_6.Question: What was the primary reason behind the antimicrobial nature of the PSS-PDA-crosslinked GO membrane?
Question_6.A: Damage to the bacterial cell wall
Question_6.Source: The solid electrostatic interaction of polyelectrolytes with the bacterial cell membrane may damage the cell wall.

Question_7.Context: The study evaluated the rejection performance of different membranes after exposure to chlorine solutions of varying concentrations.
Question_7.Question: Why did the rejection efficiency decrease on exposure to a 10,000 ppm chlorine solution?
Question_7.A: Weakening of the bond between amide linkage of crosslinked GO and free chlorine
Question_7.B: Increased interlayer spacing of graphene oxide
Question_7.Source: When the concentration is more, there is a sufficient amount of free chlorine, which may attract the amide linkage of crosslinked GO, and therefore, the bond may become too weakened to suppress the passage of salt ions.

Question_8.Context: The study assessed the antifouling characteristics of the membranes in dynamic conditions.
Question_8.Question: What was the primary reason behind the reduction in contact angle observed in the PSS-PDA-crosslinked GO membrane?
Question_8.Source: The surface charges induced by the self-assembly of the polycations and polyanions is the reason behind the significant decline in contact angle.

Question_9.Context: The study evaluated the rejection performance of different membranes after exposure to chlorine solutions of varying concentrations.
Question_9.Question: What was the primary reason behind the excellent chlorine tolerance property of the PSS-PDA-crosslinked GO membrane?
Question_9.A: Entrapment of free chlorine into primary or secondary amine of polydopamine
Question_9.B: Increased interlayer spacing of graphene oxide
Question_9.Source: The resistance towards chlorine exposure of this membrane can explain that free chlorine may be entrapped into primary or secondary amine of polydopamine.

Question_10.Context: The study investigated the rejection performance of different membranes after exposure to chlorine solutions of varying concentrations.
Question_10.Question: What was the primary reason behind the high rejection efficiency of the PSS-PDA-crosslinked GO membrane for both monovalent and divalent ions?
Question_10.A: Electrostatic interaction in addition to pore-based sieving
Question_10.Source: The PSS-PDA-crosslinked GO membrane's highest efficiency is because of electrostatic interaction in addition to the pore-based sieving.
